Award.AwardTitle: Toolbox Workshop for the AccelNet PI Meeting
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to communicate and collaborate is key to effective research teams and networks. This project focuses on enhancing this ability through a dialogue-based workshop to be held in Washington DC for newly funded members of international network-to-network collaborations as part of an awardee project meeting. The workshop builds on a decade of work by the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative to design and deliver evidence-based facilitated discussions that increase the communicative and collaborative capacity of cross-disciplinary teams. The workshop will advance knowledge along two fronts. First, the reflective discussion among participating members of the networks of networks will increase their own understandings of potential obstacles to project success and opportunities for project development. Second, the extension of the facilitative approach from research teams to larger, distributed networks of networks will provide new insights to science collaborations.

The primary goal of this workshop is to provide members of international network-to-network collaborations the opportunity to examine beliefs and values that inform their contributions as collaborators, researchers, and networks members. Workshop participants will represent newly funded projects in the Accelerating Research through International Network-to-Network Collaboration program. The workshop will be crafted for each network represented, maximizing the value of the time they spend in dialogue. The workshop will generate: (1) a team-focused conversation about the conceptual foundations of their project that can coordinate their collective thinking going forward; (2) products of a co-creation activity that will contribute to the team's process; (3) a report that offers communication and collaboration recommendations for the team's consideration; (4) a communication-focused survey tool that the teams can use to check in periodically about the status of their collaboration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Toolbox Workshop for the AccelNet PI Meeting” project (hereafter, “the project”) was designed to support the NSF Accelerating Research through International Network-to-Network Collaborations (AccelNet) Program. Directed by the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative (TDI) of Michigan State University, the project focused on enhancing the ability of the teams in the first cohort of AccelNet awardees to build international networks of networks. Each team itself represented a network, but AccelNet funding gave them the opportunity to scale up their work by combining forces with other, similarly focused networks around the world. By increasing the amount of expertise and resources, the new global networks of networks should be able to ask bigger research questions and produce research findings that have a bigger impact on the world.

 

In the project, TDI designed and delivered a two-day meeting for 2019 AccelNet awardees that provided opportunities for learning about three critical aspects of successful networks of networks, namely, coordination of resources (human and technical) around the world, evaluation of project performance, and professional development of members of the projects and especially early career scientists. These topics were the focus of a dialogue-based Toolbox workshop and a community of practice activity that enabled the awardees to learn how other teams approached these topics. Social learning like this was emphasized throughout the meeting, and teams were encouraged to compare notes and form relationships that could strengthen their ability to do the difficult work of building international networks of networks.

 

In addition to providing the awardees with opportunities to build a community of practice around three AccelNet points of emphasis, the meeting provided information about the AccelNet Program and also gave them a chance to learn from two guest speakers who had experience building successful, international networks of networks.

 

The project advanced scientific knowledge in two ways. First, it expanded the awareness AccelNet awardees have of the importance of process in developing international networks of networks. Second, it provided TDI with the opportunity to continue developing the Toolbox dialogue method, a workshop-based method that enhances communication and collaboration in complex research projects.

 

The project also had a number of broader impacts. First, by focusing on facilitating process, it helped the AccelNet projects pursue their broader impacts. Second, it helps expand the global network of transdisciplinary efforts that TDI supports, thereby bringing the method to a greater range of potential projects. Third, the project provided professional development for members of TDI, especially a post-doctoral researcher who led the effort.
